awd_titl_txt: Material Consequences of Distinct Interbacterial Modes of Aggression in Bacterial Biofilms
awd_abstract_narration:
Non-technical:

Nontechnical Summary
Bacteria often live in crowded communities, attached to surfaces. These communities are themselves a living material, and may potentially be useful in industrial and health applications. However, the utility of engineered bacterial communities is currently hampered due to limited understanding of how to control the structure of these bacterial communities. Here, the PIs will study a novel source of design rules: microbial warfare. In nature, bacteria within the same community compete for space and resources. As a result, many bacteria have evolved mechanisms to kill each other. Killing events modify the structure of bacterial communities. Broadly speaking, the mechanisms bacteria use to kill each other fit one of two categories; they either act locally, and require direct contact between cells, or they act at a distance, through toxins or antibiotics that diffuse through liquid. The PIs will uncover the material consequences of local and non-local bacterial killing, and thus develop an understanding of the design rules connecting bacterial killing to community structure. Doing so will facilitate the creation of next-generation synthetic bacterial communities with optimized structures.

Technical Summary

Bacteria are the most dominant form of life on earth. They commonly inhabit biofilms, microbial consortia composed of densely packed cells embedded in a matrix of extracellular polymeric substances and often attached to a surface. These crowded structures are ubiquitous in ecological settings and also serve as havens for host-associated bacteria that promote health and also underlie many infections. Because biofilms are densely packed, cell death and reproduction hold emergent materials consequences. When a cell dies and lyses, the biofilm structure may partially 'cave-in;' and when a cell reproduces, it pushes other cells out of its way. These cellular processes create a dynamic process where death and reproduction modify biofilm structure; and structural changes impact subsequent death and reproduction. The focus of this proposal is on cell death within biofilms that is mediated by microbial antagonistic interactions - killing. Broadly speaking, the mechanisms of intercellular killing can be classified as either local or non-local. Local killing mechanisms typically require direct contact between cells, and thus depend on the nearest neighbor interaction network of cells in biofilms. Non-local killing mechanisms typically feature diffusible secreted toxins, and thus depend on the density of killer cells surrounding a target cell. Understanding the dynamics of inter-microbial aggression will facilitate the design of antagonistic probiotics, and help elucidate the ecological role of bacterial antagonism.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This report summarizes our progress in understanding how microbial warfare impacts biofilm structure. Biofilms are surface-attached communities of bacteria that play important roles in ecology and human health, and are increasingly used for material production. However, our ability to assemble functional biofilms is severely limited. We addressed this issue by examining how biofilms form with different structures, and how microbial warfare, i.e., bacteria killing each other, can be harnessed to produce desirable biofilm structures. This work, focused around three goals, led to 11 publications.

 

Goal 1: Elucidate dynamic structure-killing feedback loops

We made significant strides in understanding bacterial competition and biofilm structure dynamics. In one paper, (Steinbach, et al., Journal of the Royal Society Interface) we revealed that dead cell debris from contact killing prevents further killing, allowing antagonistic strains to coexist. This "freezes" spatial structures in biofilms, challenging the assumption that contact killing could continue endlessly. Thus, once formed, desired structures can permanently remain in biofilms.

In five studies we made discoveries about the underlying science of the Type VI Secretion System (T6SS), a common bacterial contact killing system. We discovered that a single mutation rewires Vibrio cholerae T6SS activity between inducible and constitutive (i.e., always on) states (Ng, et al., mBio). We studied the evolution of resistance to T6SS killing and found that mutations that improve survival come at a cost to other fitness components (MacGillivray, et al., iScience). We discovered a new T6SS toxin that permeabilizes target cells (Crisan, et al., mSphere). We identified a novel defense mechanism against T6SS killing in the presence of glucose, suggesting a method to control microscopic spatial structure through macroscopic means (Crisan, et al., Scientific Reports). We investigated the fitness costs of contact killing, finding a negligible impact on growth (Zhang, et al., Ecology and Evolution), suggesting that contact killing can structure communities without significantly decreasing fitness. These discoveries suggest how to control killing thus producing a wider array of spatial patterns.

We increased understanding of non-contact-based microbial killing. We performed a broad study of many bacteria and found that most are susceptible to R2-pyocins, a non-contact killing mechanism (Mei, et al., Microbiology Spectrum). We reviewed quorum sensing circuits, explaining how this communication system synchronizes microbial warfare, like the secretion of R2-pyocins, and other behaviors across communities (Soto-Aceves, et al., Microbiology).

 

Goal 2: Understand impact of biofilm mechanics on antagonistic competitions

We made substantial progress on understanding how mechanics impact biofilm morphology. We found that small colonies form spherical caps, and revealed a critical trade-off between horizontal and vertical expansion, mediated by the contact angle at the biofilm edge (Pokhrel et al., Nature Physics). We found that biofilm geometry is the single most important factor for biofilm growth rate---even more important than cellular growth rate! We made fundamental discoveries about vertical biofilm growth using white-light interferometry (Bravo, et al., PNAS). We developed an “interface model” that accurately describes vertical growth dynamics across diverse microbes, challenging conventional growth models. Finally, we published a comprehensive review exploring how intercellular bonds influence multicellular groups, including biofilms (Thomas Day, et al., Biophysics Reviews). These works set the stage for physics-based biofilm design.

 

Goal 3: Elucidate the impact of initial conditions on local and non-local killing

We conducted systematic studies of how initial concentrations of killer cells impact the final concentration of target cells (Copeland, et al., PLoS: Computational Biology). We revealed that initial conditions are particularly crucial in small bacterial communities, with inferior competitors surviving at much higher rates in small communities compared to large ones. We performed experiments that validated these results.

 

Outreach and Mentoring

Despite COVID-19 restrictions through much of the time of this award, we focused on mentoring undergraduates, broadening participation in STEM fields. Yunker mentored 8 undergraduate researchers (3 male/6 female), including Julianne Tijani, who won GT’s highest award for undergrad biophysics research and co-authored a paper (Pokhrel, et al., Nature Physics). Hammer mentored 12 undergraduate researchers (4 male/8 female) during the course of the grant. Five earned authorship on publications supported by it. Co-PI Diggle has also spoken extensively at undergraduate focused institutions, including nine different institutions during the time of this award.

 

Conclusion

Our research has significantly advanced the understanding of the interplay between bacterial competition and biofilm structure. Our work spans length scales, from molecular mechanisms to community-level interactions, providing a comprehensive view of how competition shapes biofilm structure and function. We've uncovered novel mechanisms of coexistence, developed new tools for studying biofilm growth, and challenged existing models. These findings contribute to the potential development of biofilms as synthetic materials and open new avenues for controlling biofilm structure through manipulation of competitive interactions and growth conditions. Our work lays a strong foundation for future research, offering new insight on the relationship between bacterial warfare and community structure.
